title: Is there any example of functions f(x) and g(x) such that f(g(x)) = f(x).g(x)? - Quora

response.answer_text: If we have [math]f(x) = ax^p[/math] and [math]g(x) = bx^q[/math] Then we have [math]a(bx^q)^p = (ax^p)(bx^q)[/math] so [math]b^px^{pq} = bx^{p+q}[/math] So as long as [math]b^p = b [/math] and [math]pq=p+q[/math] this will work. That is, [math]f(x) = ax^p[/math] and [math]g(x) = x^\frac{p}{p-1}[/math] Is a class of solutions for [math]p\neq 1[/math]. Note that [math]p=0[/math] gives [math]f[/math] as any constant function and [math]g[/math] as the unit constant function. Also, [math]p=2[/math] is the other integer solution. In fact, we can see from this that if [math]f,g[/math] is a solution, [math]af,g[/math] is a solution for any constant [math]a[/math]. If [math]f[/math] is the zero function, [math]f,g[/math] is a solution for any [math]g[/math]. All the simple solutions are the ones where the function types are closed under composition and multiplication. We did it for monomials but polynomials also have this property, so we could check for those, but that would be pretty messy algebra so I’ll skip it.  Not a solution, but a property I just noticed is that if [math]x_0[/math] is a fixed point of [math]g[/math], then [math]f(g(x_0)) = f(x_0)[/math] and [math]f(x_0)g(x_0) = x_0f(x_0)[/math], so [math](x_0-1)f(x_0) = 0[/math] so either [math]x_0 = 1[/math] or [math]f(x_0) = 0[/math]. From this we can deduce that [math]f\circ g[/math] has a fixed point iff [math]f[/math] and [math]g[/math] have the same fixed point, and that fixed point is [math]x_0 = 0[/math].
